Dear Ms. Shenberger:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
Title conditions, books, records, and reports; access by department,
bureau of fire services, or local authorities; records; report;
forms; confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided to
department; failure of licensee to cooperate with investigation,
inspection, or examination.
Rule Code & (C) Providing accurate and truthful information to the department,
Section and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and household members,
Description to provide accurate and truthful information to the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Director advised a supervisor to enter falsified information such as
sibling contacts.
Investigation Complainant is anonymous.
Chief Operating Officer (COO) was contacted and interviewed
about the allegation on 10/2/24, due to the allegation involving
the Director of the Foster Care Program and the complainant was
anonymous. The COO thanked the Consultant and had no
additional information to provide.
Interview with Foster Care Specialist 1 (FCS 1) via telephone
on 11/14/24. She reported she is no longer employed at Vista
Maria. She reported Foster Care Director 1 (FCD 1) has never
given her permission to sign FCD 1’s name on documents prior to
two Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP’s) that needed to be
signed for this year’s annual audit. She reported she lives two
hours away from the agency therefore, when she schedules home
visits, she does not return back to the agency when she goes to
foster home visits. After her home visits, she goes to her home.
She reported the agency was preparing for their agency annual
audit and she needed to get signatures from a foster home before
3

the audit that was scheduled to start the next day, early morning.
She reported prior, FCD 1 told her to go to the foster home, get
the required signatures on the PATP’s and put them on her desk
for review. She reported FCD 1 left work early and was not
returning back to the office on this day. FCS 1 reported she sent
FCD 1 an email informing FCD 1 that she was going to get the
signatures for the PATP’s, which consists of a youth and his foster
care relative and would upload the documents in MiSACWIS.
FCS 1 reported she informed FCD 1 in an email she sent that she
was going to sign FCD’s 1 name on the documents. FCS 1
reported she also called FCD 1 on the telephone the next day and
informed FCD 1 on the telephone to inform the auditor that she
signed FCD’s 1 name on the PATP reports. According to the FCS
1, FCD 1 said “okay”. FCS 1 said she was in the office when she
made the telephone call to FCD 1 who was preparing for the
agency audit. She reported she was talking to FCD 1 on speaker
phone and that one of her co-workers, FCS 2, overheard the
conversation. FCS 1 reported she never thought anything would
happen as a result of signing FCD 1’s name on the documents.
She said the next thing she knew; she was being placed on
administrative leave. She said no one explained to her why she
was being placed on administrative leave, she was told not to
return back into the office until further notice. FCS 1 reported
FCD 1 was well aware that she had signed her name on two
PATP documents that occurred in the same foster home for two
reporting periods. The PATP’s were dated 11/4/23 – 2/1/24 and
4/27/24 – 7/22/24. She stated when she worked for the
department, she had been told it was okay to sign for someone
and initial it if that person was no longer available (meaning if a
worker had left the position or no longer worked for the agency).
FCS 1 admitted she was assigned the case for Foster Child A and
his siblings, and she noticed the last worker, FCS 4 did not
complete sibling visit documentation and left the case in a mess.
She said with no permission from anyone, she went into
MiSACWIS and modified the sibling visits social work contacts
which included adding face-to-face contacts. The dates for the
sibling visits that were added under social work contacts were
1/20/24, 6/15/24 and 7/20/24. It was discussed with FCS 1 that
she was not an employee at Vista Maria during those dates. FCS
1 responded that Foster Child A and his siblings were on her case
load, she was now responsible for the case, and she wanted FCD
1 to pass her audit. FCS 1 reported upon review of Foster Child
A’s case she observed notes written by FCS 4 regarding sibling
visits dates but they were not entered into MiSACWIS for the
months of January, June and July so she added them into the
4

system. FCS 1 did not have additional information. She stated
she resigned from the agency because she did not like the
“culture.” She said she made a mistake in modifying the SWC’s
because she just did not know.
Interview with Quality Director via email on 11/14/24. She
reported she interviewed the Foster Parent via phone along with
Foster Home Development Supervisor regarding the allegation,
signatures on documents and sibling visits. She reported the
Foster Parent verified the sibling visits did in fact occur by FCS 4.
The Quality Director did not go into detail of how FCS 1 received
the dates for the sibling visits.
Interview with Foster Care Specialist 2 via telephone on
11/14/24. She reported she was in the office the day of the audit
and heard FCS 1 telephone conversation with FCD 1. She said
she heard FCS 1 inform FCD 1 that she had signed FCD 1’s
name on PATP documents and to inform the auditor that FCS 1
signed the documents for FCD 1. FCS 2 said she heard FCD 1
respond, that’s fine. FCS 2 said at the time, she did not think it
was an issue or a big deal. She reported she has never signed
FCD 1 name on any of her documents nor has FCD 1 ever asked
her to do so. FCS 2 had no additional information. She only
discussed hearing about PATP documents. She did not mention
or report hearing anything about social work contacts.
Interview with Program Manager (PM) via telephone on
11/14/24. She reported FCD 1 informed her that FCS 1 allegedly
sent her an email informing her she was signing FCD 1’s name on
documents. She said FCD 1 informed PM that she never received
the email regarding her signature being signed on documents.
PM reported she did not discuss with FCD1 what documents she
was referring too. PM said this is the only information she has
received on the allegation that FCD 1 had discussed with her.
She had no additional information on PATP’s or social work
contacts when interviewed.
Interview with Foster Care Director 1 via video conference on
11/15/24. She reported that FCS 1 sent her an email saying she
was going to get signatures. FCD 1 said FCS 1 did not mention
who she was getting signatures for and afterwards, FCS 1 said in
the email she was going home. FCD 1 reported FCS 1 did say in
the email that she was going to sign FCD 1 name on the
documents and when FCD 1 reported to work the next day, she
could review the documents. FCD 1 reported when she reported
to work the next morning, there were no documents on her desk to
5

review. FCD 1 said on the second day of the agency DCWL audit,
FCS 1 brought her several documents (PATP’s) to review and
sign and that she did sign those documents and met with the
DCWL Auditor. FCD 1 said she could not identify the date of the
email because she no longer had access to her computer as she
is no longer employed with Vista Maria. FCD 1 reported she could
not recall getting a telephone call discussing the signing of PATP
documents from FCS 1. FCD 1 changed her story and reported
FCS 1 might have called her, but she did not remember, she
added, she did say okay to FCS 1 when she sent her the email
about signing FCD 1’s name on PATP documents. FCD 1
reported she had no idea that FCS 1 had entered social work
contacts into MiSACWIS. She reported she learned of this
information during the annual audit exit with the DCWL Auditor
and when FCD 2 pointed it out to her. She had no additional
information to add.
It should be noted that a discussion was held with FCD 1
regarding her inconsistency with her statements regarding the
email, and the telephone call from FCS 1 about signing PATP
documents and giving her permission to sign FCD 1’s name on
the PATP documents. FCD 1 said it was the best she could
remember, and she did not have her notes to refer to as they were
in her computer that she had to return back to Vista Maria as she
is no longer employed with the agency.
Interview with Foster Care Director 2 (FCD 2) via telephone
on 11/18/24. FCD 2 reported on 10/1/2024, Vista Maria had their
DCWL renewal audit and corrective action plan review by DCWL
Auditor. When DCWL Auditor completed her MiSACWIS audits,
there were several cases with missing sibling visits. She reported
one case in particular that was assigned by a worker who no
longer worked for the agency (FCS 4) had recent information
documented and inputted for 9/30/2024. FCD 2 said the DCWL
Auditor reported when she reviewed the case, several sibling
visits were missing sibling visits for January, February, April and
July of 2024 from this sibling group.
FCD 2 said DCWL Auditor pointed out that the sibling visits were
all added on 9/30/24 by FCS 1. FCD 2 said she spoke up during
the audit meeting and stated she was concerned about the validity
of the sibling visits due to being a member of the quality team.
She said she emailed all staff to reconcile contacts on a monthly
basis. FCD 2 reported those contacts were previously listed as not
occurring. FCD 2 said she advised FCD 1 to reach out to the
caregivers at the time of placement to determine if the visits
6

occurred. FCD 2 reported that FCD 1 reported back the caregiver
confirmed the sibling visits did occur by FCS 4 but was not
entered into the system before departing with the agency.
FCD 2 reported that FCS 1 was called to the board room and
when asked about the sibling visits, she reported Program
Manager told her the dates of the sibling visits and she inputted
the information into MiSACWIS as she was now responsible for
the case. FCD 2 reported Program Manager shared an email
verifying that the caregiver had signed the documents, and the
caregiver gave the agency permission to contact her directly about
signing the documents. FCD 2 explained the caregiver reported
the handwriting might look different because she had a stroke and
her writing was different.
FCD 2 reported that FCD 1 presented several PATPs for different
reporting periods to DCWL Auditor. DCWL Auditor reviewed the
signatures and signatures for the same caregiver were signed
differently. FCD 2 said DCWL Auditor made a comment about the
signatures, which prompted Program Manager to review the other
PATPs that were subsequently going to be provided to DCWL
Auditor. FCD 2 reported during Program Manager’s review,
Program Manager stated she could tell FCD 1’s signature was not
signed by FCD 1. FCD 1 looked at the documents and stated
signatures were not signed by her. FCD 2 reported FCD 1 did not
state that she told anyone they could sign for her on these PATPs.
Program Manager also compared Foster Child A’s signature and
reported the signature was not familiar to what she had seen from
this youth in the past. It is undetermined if Foster Child A’s
signature was not his signature. Foster Child A did not make
himself available for an interview to answer this question and
neither FCD1 nor FCS 1 state that FCS 1 signed Foster Child A’s
signature on any of the PATP’s that were in question.
Interview with Foster Home Development Supervisor via
telephone on 11/18/24. She reported she knows very little about
the allegations. She reported she did interview Foster Parent with
the Quality Director, and the Foster Parent confirmed that the
sibling visits did occur with FCS 4, but that Foster Parent was
unable to verify the dates or months. She said she has never
required her supervisors to back date forms, nor has she ever had
that type of conversation with FCD 1. She had no additional
information.
Interview with Adoption Supervisor via telephone regarding
the allegation on 11/18/24. She reported she has no knowledge
7

of the allegations and stated it was not best practice to have a
subordinate to sign any documents in the supervisor’s place.
Interview with Foster Care Specialist (FCS 3) via telephone on
11/18/24. She reported she has no knowledge of the allegation
and that she has never been placed in a situation where she
signed her supervisor’s name on a document. FCS 3 reported if a
document is late or overdue, it’s late and she would take
responsibility. No additional information was added.
Interview with Foster Parent via telephone on 11/20/24. Foster
Parent reported she was unaware of what documents were
falsified. She reported she signs many documents, but she did
not know what she was signing. She said when the workers come
into her home (there had been several workers, no names were
identified) asked her to sign documents, she signed her name on
the forms/paper. She said she did not have a time period of
when she signed the documents because every time a worker
came to her home, she was asked to sign documents. She had no
additional information to add, and several people had questioned
her about signing documents. Foster Parent reported Foster Child
A visits with his siblings weekly.
It is noted that four siblings were placed together in a relative
foster home since coming into care. Foster Child A was placed
from his siblings on 8/14/24, into another unrelated foster home.
He has weekly sibling visits with his siblings in the relative foster
home.
Interview with DCWL Auditor via telephone on 11/20/24. She
reported during her exit conference and after reviewing several
cases, updated services plans and PATP’s dating back to 2023,
she discovered there were PATP’s that had just been entered into
MiSACWIS on 9/30/2024 that appeared to have the same
penmanship for all needed signatures including the foster parent,
previous case worker and supervisor. She said she questioned
the validity of the signatures and inquired about the signatures on
the documents. She reported that FCD 2 spoke up and reported
the documents were not signed previously upon during her
monthly quarterly reviews. She reported the previous caseworker
of that particular case had resigned from the agency and did not
complete the signatures. Another caseworker, FCS 1 was now
assigned to the case. The DCWL Auditor reported she reviewed
the social work contacts of the case in question and discovered
the social work contacts were modified by FCS 1 dating back to
1/20/24. DCWL Auditor noted FCS 1 was not employed at the
8

agency during that time and that her employment did not start until
August of 2024.
Attempted telephone calls were made to interview Foster
Child A on 11/15/24, 11/18/24 and 11/20/24. A call back
message was left. To date, no response.
Email that was allegedly written by FCS 1 and sent to FCD 1 was
not reviewed due to not being obtained by FCS 1 or FCD 1. Both
reported they did not obtain copies of the email when they
departed from the agency.
Documents Reviewed:
-FCS 1 personnel file – FCS 1 was hired with Vista Maria
8/6/2024 – 10/30/24. Two months and 24 days. There was no
discipline action in her personnel file.
-FCD 1 Personnel file- FCD1 was hired as the foster director
2/23 – 11/12/24. There was no disciplinary action in her file.
-FCS 4 personnel file – FCS 4 was terminated from the agency
on 8/27/24. She had no discipline action in her personnel file.
-Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP) dated 11/4/23 – 2/1/24
and 4/27/24 – 7/22/24. Both of these PATP’s were entered into
MiSACWIS on 9/30/24 with the signatures of the previous worker,
FCS 4, foster parent and FCD 1. All three signatures appeared to
be the same writing.
-Foster Child A’s case record was reviewed. He was placed
with Vista Maria in December of 2020. It was noted that his
signature on the PATP’s for that time period was signed and dated
using print writing.
-Social Work Contacts were reviewed from the time period of
11/4/23 – 2/1/24 and 4/27/24 – 7/22/24. These social work
contacts were entered into MiSACWIS on 9/30/2024 by FCS 1.
FCS 1 reported no one gave her permission to modify the social
work contacts. This was now her case, and she wanted FCD 1 to
pass her audit.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as the Parent Agency Treatment
plans (PATP) were uploaded in MiSACWIS on 9/30/24. The
PATP's were dated 11/4/23 -2/1/23 and 4/27/24 -7/22/24. Foster
Care Specialist 1 admitted she was given permission to sign
Foster Care Director 1 name on the PATP's and she emailed
Foster Care Director 1 about the signatures and telephoned
Foster Care Director 1 the next morning about the signatures. All
of the signatures on the documents had the same writing. FCS 1
admitted that she modified the social work contacts for the same
9

case because FCS 4 did not enter the information into
MiSACWIS, and she wanted the agency to pass the DCWL audit.
Foster Care Director 2 reported that when she viewed these same
documents (PATP’s) prior for quality review, the documents did
not have signatures on them. FCD 1 was inconsistent with her
statements and reported vaguely remembering what she
discussed with FCS 1.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan,
the continuation of issuing a second provisional license from the 2024 renewal
inspection dated 11/6/2024, is recommended.
